newsitem.title: ITALY: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Thursday, February 20.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Italy - Thursday, February 20.

text.p: Following are some of the top headlines in leading Italian newspapers.

* Prime Minister Romano Prodi said he had prepared the framework for a fresh budget to ensure Italy is a founder member of the single European currency and would be launching the package in the coming weeks. Controversy over a minibudget is starting to undermine the ruling coalition (all).
* Minister of Industry Pierluigi Bersani said that a planned mini-budget for 1997 would be limited as Italian economic growth early this year was steady (all).
* Treasury Carlo Azeglio Ciampi said he was confident Eurostat would approve Italy's one-off "Eurotax" to ensure the country becomes a founding member of EMU (all).

* Hard-left Communist Refoundation party leader Fausto Bertinotti said he was ready to discuss the government's planned mini-budget but would not accept cuts in public spending or new taxes. He also ruled out the idea that the mini-budget might try to raise cash from pensioners (all).
* Former communist Democratic Party of the Left (PDS) opens its annual national congress today in Rome (all).

* The managing director of state railway Ferrovie dello Stato Giancarlo Cimoli announced the company will be split in two sections, one managing the rail lines and the infrastructure and the second the train and rolling stock. Cimoli is expected to discuss reforms today with trade union representatives (all).
* Italian bond futures ticked higher after Prodi confirmed a new mini-budget would be introduced. The Italian currency inched up off recent lows against the mark after Tuesday's sharp fall (all).
* Mondadori fell another 5.24 percent after the shock resignation of managing director Paolo Forlin. A board meeting is expected today (all).
* Gianni Zandano chairman of Istituto San Paolo di Torino is said to back the model of a public company for the privatisation of the bank, with no core shareholders (Corriere del Sera).
Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
